The two-and-a-half year-old Yemeni Civil War has indeed been marked by atrocities against civilians. While Amnesty International reports more than 15,000 civilians have been killed in this tragic struggle, I do not predict a systematic, targeted campaign of killing directed at civilians at all likely, mostly because my research does not reveal a pattern of large-scale atrocities like those that were committed by ISIL, and because actors within Yemen are unlikely to carry out such atrocities on such a grand scale. Third, any Saudi or Iranian-backed Huthi rebel strikes that produce collateral damage, and they frequently do, will not reach the scale referenced within the scope of the question.

To begin, let’s start with the EarlyWarning Project, and the structural parameters used by them. In 2014,2015, and  2016  the structural probabilities are 1.7, 3.7 and 7.3 respectively. Doing a linear extrapolation out would give a probability of 16 percent. Given one of the largest indicators of genocide is regime change, and to properly forecast, it has to be before it happens (i.e. if you want to forecast what happens in 2018, you have to do it in 2017), I’m going to bump the probability to 9.5%. The group opinion poll is 15 percent%. With that in mind, i’m going to bump my base rate up from 11 to 11.5%  Here’s the deal yall, whomever is reading this. First of all, in a period of a year, only 303 civilians have been killed by my count. Some of which, do not seem organized enough to be considered a genocide. Granted, it is only October, so let’s scaled it up to 350 kills by the end of the year.  Second of all, the killings were made by several groups, some being the Houthi, and the pro-hadi group of soldiers. Third of all, some of the killings the intent was not ethnically based/or grouped based.  So there needs to be over a 300 percent increase in killings for a genocide to maybe happen.

The answer will depend on how the EWP evaluates its specific criteria for resolution. Civilian casualties in Yemen are increasing, but deaths in bombings will most likely be considered "accidental killing of civilians in war". However, if the fight for Hodeidah continues or becomes a full out siege, the blockade of food and medical aid will likely lead to several thousand deaths from starvation and disease, presumably falling in the category of "policies that knowingly result in widespread death".  https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/sep/26/huge-spike-in-yemen-violence-as-civilian-deaths-rise-by-164-in-four-months-hodeidah
